Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Pathways to ecological generalism and the abundance-occupancy relationship in small-mammal communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how small-scale experiments explain widespread patterns is a major challenge in the field of ecology. While experiments reveal mechanisms, their value is uncertain if these mechanisms cannot account for the large-scale patterns that characterize the natural world. One such common pattern is that widespread species tend to be abundant, while species with restricted distributions are often rare. This project, from an early career investigator, pursues a novel approach to determine how resource use by individuals can explain this pattern. The project will integrate experimental data collected on individuals with new models to extend individual results to populations and then to communities across large landscapes. The research will engage undergraduate students from Wyoming, who will participate in research along with Kenyan students, and leverages current NSF support by using an ongoing experiment in Kenya. Results will contribute to a reference library of savanna plants at the Smithsonian Institution that is shared with museums in Kenya. Data from this project will be publicly available.

Correlations between abundance and occupancy are among the most pervasive in ecology: species with expansive distributions tend to be locally abundant, whereas those with restricted distributions tend to be locally rare. This pattern has long captivated ecologists, but proposed hypotheses to explain it have proved very difficult to test. This project pursues the resource-breadth hypotheses by focusing specifically on dietary breadth of individuals. Resource use will be quantified by sequencing fecal DNA in a species-rich guild of small, herbivorous mammals. Individual consumer-resource interactions will be integrated with estimates of fitness and population growth for constituent species in large-scale communities to discern whether ecological generalists are more abundant where they co-occur with dietary specialists and to identify the pathways through which ecological generalism is manifested in survival and recruitment rates. An ongoing herbivore exclusion experiment provides a backdrop of shifting resource dynamics across which a guild of small mammals is intensively monitored, and thus an excellent opportunity to test the resource-breath hypothesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a tendency for ecological communities to be composed of a few common, widespread species and many rare, restricted ones—this pattern holds for animals as diverse as sharks, songbirds, snakes, and snails. How and why does this happen? One long-standing idea proposes that the common, widespread species are “ecological generalists”, capable of thriving on a wide range of foods. On the other hand, uncommon species are thought to be pickier in what, when, and where they eat. Understanding the reasons for commonness and rarity can offer valuable information for species conservation.

I tested this idea—the resource abundance hypothesis—in central Kenya with a diverse community of small (<150 g) mammals, like fringe-tailed gerbils, pouched mice, rufous elephant shrews, and so forth. This required understanding how individual animals within populations selected food, compared to how available that food was in their surroundings.

My research team and I live-trapped small mammals six times per year in a coordinated network of experimental plots (the UHURU, or Ungulate Herbivory Under Small Mammal Uncertainty, experiment). This experiment excludes or allows large mammalian herbivores (LMH; e.g., elephant, giraffe, zebra, antelopes) in 18 1-ha plots in an African savanna. UHURU is located at the Mpala Research Centre in Kenya. Three blocks (each containing an open [unfenced] control and fenced exclusion plot) are located at each of three sites along the rainfall gradient (“rainfall sites”). The critical feature of UHURU for the current proposal is that the interaction of LMH exclusion and rainfall variability causes marked changes in plant-community structure and composition—and thus food availability for small mammals—among plots. Against the backdrop of this variation in food availability, our team marks and recaptures small mammals in each open and exclusion plot.

I discovered that abundant, widespread small mammals consumed more foods from their environment compared to rare, restricted species, thus supporting the resource breadth hypothesis. Diet diversity increasing as population density of small-mammal species increased, as quantified by high-throughput metabarcoding of fecal samples in collaboration with Brown University.

Three scientific manuscripts are in preparation. Four presentations were given on this work at the American Society of Mammalogists meeting and the Ecological Society of America meeting. This project has provided training and professional development to (1) two Master’s students; (2) a U.S. project manager; and (3) two Kenyan field technicians. The support provided through this award also has allowed us to maintain the UHURU experiment, in which eight investigators from five U.S. institutions currently work. Additionally, and from the financial support in this grant, I taught two undergraduate field courses through Mpala Research Centre (supporting 15 undergraduate students from the University of Wyoming). Finally, this work was used to support the UHURU (Ungulate Herbivory Under Rainfall Uncertainty) experiment, used in ongoing research projects from personnel around the globe.
